snippet: While previous exoduses by investors from emerging markets have caused bank failures, bankruptcies and layoffs, the latest retrenchment has been much milder.
abstract: Previous exoduses by investors from emerging markets have caused bank failures, bankruptcies and layoffs, but latest downturn, which began in August, has been much more modest; Federal Reserve's decision to continue its economic stimulus campaign may relieve some companies and government leaders in developing countries.

byline.original: By KEITH BRADSHER, SIMON ROMERO and CEYLAN YEGINSU
byline.contributor: Keith Bradsher reported from Jakarta, Simon Romero from Rio de Janeiro and Ceylan Yeginsu from Istanbul. Neha Thirani Bagri contributed reporting from Mumbai.

lead_paragraph: While previous exoduses by investors from emerging markets have caused bank failures, bankruptcies and layoffs, the latest retrenchment has been much milder.

headline.main: Breathing Room for Emerging Markets Watching Money Flee
headline.print_headline: Shock on Wall St. and Relief Abroad
